title: Parking warden lurks in the RAIN for family to be 'one second' late
text:
A parking warden has been captured slapping a parking ticket on a visitor's car after waiting 20 minutes for them to exceed their time limit by 'one second'.

They waited for the man and a teenage boy to park outside the Fishing Heritage Centre at Alexandra Dock in Grimsby, before creeping over at 12.30pm last Sunday.

The pictured warden had waited in an 'almost empty carpark' and braved the miserable weather to issue the ticket.

A parking warden (pictured) 'watched and waited' 20 minutes until a man and his son were 'one second' over their time limit at the Fishing Heritage Centre at Alexandra Dock in Grimsby, last Sunday

The North East Lincolnshire Council parking warden waited for the pair to buy a pay-and-display ticket outside, according to a motorist.

The driver told the Grimsby Live: 'There was only one or two other cars parked up. It was an almost empty car park. He was clearly watching and waiting to strike.

'It was as if he'd waited for one second past their ticket time to issue a ticket - disgusting.'

Parking fines at the Centre cost between £50 and £70 but this is halved if they manage to pay within two weeks

And on returning, they found parking tickets stuck to their windscreen.

Parking fines at the Centre cost between £50 and £70 but this is halved if they pay within two weeks

The motorist asked 'what's the point of coming into Grimsby' if people cannot park in an empty car park on a Sunday for the main attraction.

They said: 'Why can't the council develop a free-for-two-hours policy or make parking free on a Sunday like they have in North Lincolnshire?'

By loosening the parking rules, there would be more people coming into the town.

A coach driver has been previously fined £50 for parking in the Fishing Heritage Centre's carpark despite vehicles being allowed a free drop-off slot (Centre pictured)

But the 'need to generate revenues' was key driver for policy and means it can be quite difficult trying to figure out the best options, according to North East Lincolnshire Council.

The spokesperson said 'we always appreciate peoples' views' on parking.

But this is not the first incident of this kind as a coach driver was fined £50 for parking in the 'coach-only' space to drop off children at the Grimsby attraction.

It was claimed that a pay-and-display ticket was needed but was later found out coach drivers are given free parking for collecting visitors.

Speaking at the time, the coach driver told the Mirror: 'You shouldn't have to pay to park when you're bringing a group of children to be educated in a place like this, you're only doing your job - it seems a bit unfair.

'I think the council is just clutching at straws trying to get every driver they can now.'
description: A parking warden has been captured 'watching and waiting to strike' a man and a teenage boy with parking ticket for 20 minutes at the Fishing Heritage Centre carpark in Grimsby, last Sunday.
